Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Single Cell Quantification of Splice Variants and Epigenetic Regulation of Splicing

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Different cell lines and tissue types are often characterized by the expression of distinct alternatively spliced transcripts, implicating epigenetic processes in establishing stable splicing patterns during mitotic cell divisions that accompany development and differentiation. This project will develop a powerful and exquisitely sensitive technology to detect and quantify low abundance mRNA transcripts in single cells invoking the "Plasmon nanoruler" concept using gold nanoparticle sensors. The method will be applied to test the hypothesis that pre-mRNA splicing patterns are mitotically inherited. Aims include: optimizing sensor design and delivery modules for the detection and quantification of multiple splice variants in single cells, and defining splice variant profiles and heritability of splicing patterns in single cells and their progeny. Expected deliverables are: development of a Plasmon nanoruler hyperspectral imaging platform to detect and quantify up to three splice variants in single cells without amplification steps; definition of experimental conditions for utilizing nanoprobes for intracellular mRNA quantification; and knowledge on the heritability of splicing. This high-risk approach will set the precedent for understanding and quantifying the heritability of splicing at single cell resolution. Moreover, once developed, the technology can be adapted by multiple investigators for future studies, including: detecting dynamic expression of transcripts from any desired gene in single cells across multiple genetic, developmental and environmental conditions; identifying rare phenotypes based on differential expression of splice variants; and visualization mRNA localization and trafficking.

Broader Impacts: Educational impact includes cross-disciplinary training of graduate and undergraduate students in the fields of biophysics, biochemistry, and biology. Graduate students will develop their professional and entrepeurship skills through one-on-one coaching from the PIs, as well as through seminars offered by Purdue's Instructional and Professional Development seminar series. Graduate students will hone their instructional and mentoring skills by supervising undergraduate research interns recruited through several ongoing programs at Purdue University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RESEARCH OUTCOMES

i) Design and development of instrumentation to detect nanoparticle probes targeting mRNA in single cells.

ii) Development of quantification algorithms that interface between the DMD and CCD to switch between rapid speficic-wavelength and high-resolution whole wavelength range scanning.

iii) Extension of the methods to rapid scanning and the super-resolution schemes to monitor dynamics.

iv) Integration of a fluorescence module for validation of the hyperspectral imaging system

TRAINING OUTCOMES

Professional development is a key aspect of this effort. Training of personnel in cross-disciplinary skills is given priority. In addition, engaging undergraduates and women are central to our efforts.

i) Dr. Xiaolei Wang (a Physicist) was hired to develop the instrumentation. She is now being trained in Nanoparticle probe preparation and basic biology. She is developing the instrument for rapid scanning with super-resolution accuracy. Two undergraduates were cross trained – one in developing the software (Mahesh Babu Gorantla from Computer Science) and the other student in building the control system (Pablo Jimenez-Corredor).

ii) Tiffany Young, graduate student, assisted in generating reagents.

iii) Hunter Balduf, a Biochemistry Graduate student (Dr. Kirchmaier’s lab) assisted with developing strategies for characterizing major splicing patterns of target transcripts in candidate cell lines, functionalizing nanoparticles, developing microscopy-based pedigree mapping methods.

iv) Yi Cui, a Graduate student (Ph.D) in Agricultural and Biological Engineering assisted in developing nanoparticle probes for the detection of epigenetic modifications in cancer cells. Dr. Cui is now a scientist at PNNL.

Xunpeng Jiang, a transfer student from China was involved in the project. He helped in the synthesis of nanorods.

Other

 (i) Drs. Kirchmaier and Irudayaraj are part of an Epigenetics Consortium comprised of several faculty from Purdue University, IUPUI-Indianapolis, and Indiana University, Bloomington. In collaboration with several members of this group, Drs. Irudayaraj and Kirchmaier have ongoing projects to develop the single molecule technologies to assess chromatin modification patterns. 

 (ii) As part of integrating ongoing research at Purdue into the Biochemistry Graduate Program and PULSe Graduate Program curricula, Dr. Kirchmaier includes teaching modules on splicing and epigenetic processes for the Macromolecules (BCHM695) course and the Regulation of Gene Expression in Eukaryotes II (BCHM695C) for first and second year graduate students. 

(iii) Dr. Kirchmaier was actively involved in developing content, applying for and obtaining American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, ASBMB, accreditation of the Undergraduate Biochemistry Degree Program by the Department of Biochemistry at Purdue in 2013-2014.

(v) As part of our cross-disciplinary educational efforts to train students at the intersection between biology and engineering, Dr. Irudayaraj has helped develop a new Biological Engineering Training Group within the PULSe Graduate Program at Purdue.

(vi) Other efforts include recruitment of undergraduate students through the Discovery Undergraduate Research Internship and the Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship programs at Purdue. Over the past year (2015-2016), 2 undergraduate students have been trained on the system developed by Dr. Xiaolei Wang.
